description: Photos: Aretha Franklin fans pay respects at viewings in Detroit
title: Photos: Aretha Franklin fans pay respects at viewings in Detroit
title_page: Photos: Aretha Franklin fans pay respects at viewings in Detroit
text:
1 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP Aretha Franklin's coffin lies at Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya, Pool)
2 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP Aretha Franklin's coffin lies at Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, 2018 of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya, Pool)
3 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP Aretha Franklin lies in her casket at Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya, Pool)
4 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP A member of the public becomes emotional viewing Aretha Franklin's coffin at Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya, Pool)
5 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP A woman becomes emotional viewing Aretha Franklin's coffin at Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya, Pool)
6 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP A well wisher carries a sign to view Aretha Franklin's casket at Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya, Pool)
7 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP Members of the public view Aretha Franklin's coffin at Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a visitation in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya, Pool)
8 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP Aretha Franklin's coffin lies at Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya, Pool)
9 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP Aretha Franklin's coffin lies at Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya, Pool)
10 / 58
Carlos Osorio/AP CORRECTS TO 1940, NOT 1936 - Swanson Funeral Home's 1940 LaSalle hearse is parked outside the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018, in Detroit. The hearse transported the gold casket of Aretha Franklin to the museum where she will lay in state for two days. (AP Photo/Carlos Osorio)
11 / 58
Tanya Moutzalias/AP Joye Tyler, of Detroit, sings Aretha Franklin's "Respect" before walking inside the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History in Detroit Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018, to pay her respects to Franklin on the first day of public viewing.(Tanya Moutzalias/Ann Arbor News via AP)
12 / 58
Tanya Moutzalias/AP "I think the legacy that she leaves will be remembered for years to come," said Charlotte Price, right, 62, of Columbus, Ohio. "Her music will never die," added Kathy McPike, left, of Columbus, Ohio after the two paid their respects to Aretha Franklin on the first day of the public viewing at Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History in Detroit Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. (Tanya Moutzalias/Ann Arbor News via AP)
13 / 58
Tanya Moutzalias/AP Imogen King-Dugan, of Farmington Hills, Michigan, wears a t-shirt covered in images of Aretha Franklin while waiting in line to pay her respects on the first day of public viewing for Aretha Franklin at the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History in Detroit, Aug. 28, 2018. (Tanya Moutzalias/Ann Arbor News via AP)
14 / 58
Tanya Moutzalias/AP Cenita Walker-Scott, of Chicago, dances to legendary singer Aretha Franklin's song "Rock Steady" being played while waiting in line outside of Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History in Detroit to pay her respects to Franklin on the first day of public viewing, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Thousands are expected to pour into Detroit's Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History on Tuesday and Wednesday to pay their final respects to Franklin. (Tanya Moutzalias/Ann Arbor News-MLive.com via AP)
15 / 58
Tanya Moutzalias/AP Rochelle Hampton, left, of Warren, Mich., and Imogen King-Dugan, of Farmington Hills, Mich, dance along to "Freeway of Love" being played from a cell phone after a 1956 pink Cadillac pulled up to Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History in Detroit during the public viewing for legendary singer Aretha Franklin Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Thousands are expected to pour into Detroit's Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History on Tuesday and Wednesday to pay their final respects to Franklin. (Tanya Moutzalias/Ann Arbor News-MLive.com via AP)
16 / 58
Tanya Moutzalias/AP Joye Tyler, of Detroit, sings Aretha Franklin's "Respect" before walking inside the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History in Detroit Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018, to pay her respects to Franklin on the first day of public viewing.(Tanya Moutzalias/Ann Arbor News via AP)
17 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP People stand outside the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History in line for a public visitation for Aretha Franklin in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya)
18 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP People take a photo while in line outside the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation for Aretha Franklin in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya)
19 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP A Pink Cadillac sits outside the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation for legendary singer Aretha Franklin in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, 2018 of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya)
20 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP People wait in line outside the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation for legendary singer Aretha Franklin in Detroit, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, 2018 of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya)
21 / 58
Carlos Osorio/AP A vendor sells Aretha Franklin photos and T-shirts outside the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History where Franklin is lying in state, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018, in Detroit. (AP Photo/Carlos Osorio)
22 / 58
Carlos Osorio/AP Fans wait in line at the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History where Aretha Franklin is lying in state, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018, in Detroit. (AP Photo/Carlos Osorio)
23 / 58
Carlos Osorio/AP Hundreds of members of Delta Sigma Theta have paid tribute to their soror, Aretha Franklin at the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018, in Detroit. The sorority's traditional Omega Omega service lasted nearly an hour, saluting Franklin with song, scripture and words. Franklin, who was inducted into Delta Sigma Theta as an honorary member in 1992, was remembered as for her regal presence and love of her community. (AP Photo/Carlos Osorio)
24 / 58
Carlos Osorio/AP A member of Delta Sigma Theta holds an Aretha Franklin tribute as they pay tribute to the legendary singer at the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History, Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018, in Detroit. The sorority's traditional Omega Omega service lasted nearly an hour, saluting Franklin with song, scripture and words. Franklin, who was inducted into Delta Sigma Theta as an honorary member in 1992, was remembered as for her regal presence and love of her community. (AP Photo/Carlos Osorio)
25 / 58
Paul Sancya/AP A woman signs a poster outside the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation for Aretha Franklin in Detroit, Wednesday, Aug. 29, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya)

Paul Sancya/AP People in line reach for photos being handed out outside the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History during a public visitation for Aretha Franklin in Detroit, Wednesday, Aug. 29, 2018. Franklin died Aug. 16, of pancreatic cancer at the age of 76. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya)

29 / 58
Scott Olson/Getty Images DETROIT, MI - AUGUST 28: Fans of Aretha Franklin attend a viewing for the soul music legend at the Charles H. Wright Museum of African-American History on August 28, 2018 in Detroit, Michigan. Franklin will lie in repose at the museum today and tomorrow for the public to pay their respects. Franklin's funeral will be held Friday at Greater Grace Temple. (Photo by Scott Olson/Getty Images)

Carlos Osorio/AP The gold casket of legendary singer Aretha Franklin leaves the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History, late Tuesday, Aug. 28, 2018, in Detroit. Franklin died Aug. 16 and will be laid to rest on Friday after several days of tributes in Detroit. (AP Photo/Carlos Osorio)
39 / 58
Scott Olson/Getty Images DETROIT, MI - AUGUST 28: The remains of Aretha Franklin are placed into a hearse outside of the Charles H. Wright Museum of African-American History following a day-long public viewing on August 28, 2018 in Detroit, Michigan. Franklin will lie in repose at the museum for another day-long public viewing tomorrow. Franklin's funeral will be held Friday at Greater Grace Temple. (Photo by Scott Olson/Getty Images)

(AP Photo/Carlos Osorio)
